facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 49 of 1961 filed by special leave from Madras High Court judgment dated August 30, 1960

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CriminalAppeal No. 49 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 30, 1960, of the Madras High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 468 of 1960 and referred Trial No. 38 of 1960.

facts.text: Madras High Court judgment in Criminal Appeal No. 468 of 1960 and Referred Trial No. 38 of 1960 dated August 30, 1960

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 30, 1960, of the Madras High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 468 of 1960 and referred Trial No. 38 of 1960. N. Sethi, for the appellant., Ganpathy Iyer and T. M. Sen, for the respondent. 1961. September 27.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 27, 1961 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. September 27. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is an appeal against the judgment of the High Court of Madras, with special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: Appellant convicted under s. 302 I.P.C. and sentenced to death for murder of Elumalai on January 24, 1960 at Kannankurichi

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was companyvicted under s. 302, I.P.C., and sentenced to death for the murder of one Elumalai on January 24, 1960, at Kannankurichi. The facts of the case are simple Two days before this occurrence the appellant Muniappan and Elumalai had a quarrel at a tea.

facts.text: Two days before January 24, 1960, appellant Muniappan and Elumalai had a quarrel at a tea stall

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case are simple Two days before this occurrence the appellant Muniappan and Elumalai had a quarrel at a tea. stall. Though the quarrel really was between the appellant and some others, Elumalai had intervened in that quarrel, and made some remarks about the appellant, and had advised the party opposite to him to make a companylaint.

facts.text: Elumalai intervened in the quarrel and advised opposite party to make a complaint

anchor.surface_text: Though the quarrel really was between the appellant and some others, Elumalai had intervened in that quarrel, and made some remarks about the appellant, and had advised the party opposite to him to make a companylaint. Two reports of that incident were made, one by the appellant and the other by his rivals.

facts.text: Two reports made of the quarrel incident, one by appellant and one by rivals

anchor.surface_text: Two reports of that incident were made, one by the appellant and the other by his rivals. On January 24, 1960, at about 12.30 P.m., P.W. I Muthuswami Udayar was having a bath when he heard Elumalai calling out to him ,Mama.

facts.text: On January 24, 1960 at about 12.30 P.M., PW1 Muthuswami Udayar heard Elumalai calling 'Mama' while bathing

anchor.surface_text: On January 24, 1960, at about 12.30 P.m., P.W. I Muthuswami Udayar was having a bath when he heard Elumalai calling out to him ,Mama. Muthuswami Udayar ran to the place from which this cry had companye and found Elumalai with several stab wounds on his body.

facts.text: Muthuswami Udayar found Elumalai with several stab wounds on his body

anchor.surface_text: Muthuswami Udayar ran to the place from which this cry had companye and found Elumalai with several stab wounds on his body. Muthuawami Udayar questioned Elumalai, and the latter told him that it was the appellant Muniappan who had caused injuries to him.

facts.text: Elumalai told Muthuswami Udayar that appellant Muniappan caused injuries to him

anchor.surface_text: Muthuawami Udayar questioned Elumalai, and the latter told him that it was the appellant Muniappan who had caused injuries to him. Muthuswami gave first aid to Elumalai, and meanwhile Elian alias Kundaswami  P.W.2  and K.R. Perumal  P.W.3  also, arrived on the scene.

facts.text: Elumalai carried to Police Station House 80 yards away by PW1, PW2, PW3

anchor.surface_text: These persons carried Elumalai to the Police Station House which was at a distance of about 80 yards. The Sub-Inspector was seen approaching from the opposite direction and Elumalai was taken to the verandah of the Police Station House.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector recorded statement of Elumalai at Police Station verandah

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Inspector immediately started recording the statement of Elumalai. After Elumalai had spoken one companypete sentence, he companyld number speak any further, and though he was given some soda-water to drink, it was found that he companyld number swallow it and bad, in fact, died.

facts.text: Elumalai died after speaking one sentence in dying declaration, thumb impression taken after death

anchor.surface_text: After Elumalai had spoken one companypete sentence, he companyld number speak any further, and though he was given some soda-water to drink, it was found that he companyld number swallow it and bad, in fact, died. The Sub-Inspector thereupon took the thumb-impression of Elumalai upon the statement as recorded, and four other witnesses also signed or put their thumb marks on it.

facts.text: Muniappan reached Police Station after few minutes and surrendered

anchor.surface_text: Muniappan also reached the Police Station House after a few minutes and virtually surrendered himself to the police. One of his clothes, which was stained with blood, was seized and in one of his pockets was found a sheath which was also seized as presumably belonging to the knife with which the stab injuries were caused.

facts.text: Blood-stained cloth and sheath seized from Muniappan

anchor.surface_text: One of his clothes, which was stained with blood, was seized and in one of his pockets was found a sheath which was also seized as presumably belonging to the knife with which the stab injuries were caused. On a statement by Muniappan the Police went to a garden and recovered from there a knife which later ,Was found to be stained with human blood.

facts.text: Knife recovered from garden on statement by Muniappan, stained with human blood

anchor.surface_text: On a statement by Muniappan the Police went to a garden and recovered from there a knife which later ,Was found to be stained with human blood. Investigation disclosed that this knife together with the sheath was purchased by Muniappan from Ameer Khan  P.W. 6  on the evening of January 23, 1960.

facts.text: Knife and sheath purchased by Muniappan from PW6 Ameer Khan on evening of January 23, 1960

anchor.surface_text: Investigation disclosed that this knife together with the sheath was purchased by Muniappan from Ameer Khan  P.W. 6  on the evening of January 23, 1960. The police therefore charged Muniappan with an offence under s. 302 I.P.C.

facts.text: Two courts below convicted appellant of murder and sentenced to death

anchor.surface_text: The two companyrts below companyvicted the appellant of the offence of murder and sentenced him to death. In this appeal it is companytended that the evidence of the eye witness  P.W. 2  and the statement of the appellant made to the Doctor, who examined him, having been excluded,

facts.text: Appellant had injury on thumb of left hand

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had an injury on his thumb which he apparently got in attempting to stab Elumalai. The injury was situated on the thumb of his left hand on the lateral side and must have been  1  1958 S. C. R. 552. A. I. R.  1958  S. C. 168 caused when he struck Elumalai repeatedly holding him with his left hand and wielding the weapon with his right hand.

facts.text: Appellant surrendered to police at 12.40 P.M., within ten minutes of occurrence

anchor.surface_text: There is also the companyduct of the appellant in surrendering himself to the police at 12.40 P.m. that is to say, within ten minutes of the occurrence. The appellant had an injury on his thumb which he apparently got in attempting to stab Elumalai.

facts.text: Dying declaration by Elumalai: 'Sir, This day 24th January, 1960, in the numbern at 12.30 Muniappan, son of Kola Goundan of Kannankurichi stabbed me in my body with knife.'

anchor.surface_text: The dying declaration in the present case was as follows Sir, This day 24th January, 1960, in the numbern at 12.30 Muniappan, son of Kola Goundan of Kannankurichi stabbed me in my body with knife. Soon after be said these words, his speech stopped. His life was gone.  Left thumb impression of  Elumalai. witnesses- 1.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds dying declaration complete and admissible

anchor.surface_text: Here, the accusation against the appellant was companylete, and there is numberhing to show that Elumalai wished to say anything more or that he had any thing more to add. In so far as the dying declaration, goes, it is a companyplete.

In this appeal it is contended that the evidence of the eye witness P.W. 2 and the statement of the appellant made to the Doctor, who examined him, having been excluded, there was no sufficient evidence in the case if the dying declaration recorded by, the Sub-Inspector is excluded. The main argument

issues.text: what is the admissibility and probative value of the dying declaration described as an incomplete document completed dishonestly by getting the thumb impression after death

anchor.surface_text: there was no sufficient evidence in the case if the dying declaration recorded by, the Sub-Inspector is excluded. issues.text: whether this dying declaration interrupted by death ensuing suddenly is admissible in evidence

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Inspector should have left the document as it was, without taking the thumb mark of the dead man, but we do not feel compelled to hold that he did so out of any improper motive, inasmuch as he had noted that the man was dead before the thumb impression was taken. That also was his testimony in court, and that of the attesting witnesses. The fact, however, remains that the dying declaration was interrupted by death ensuing suddenly. The question is whether this dying declaration is admissible in evidence.

issues.text: whether the dying declaration is complete notwithstanding interruption by death

anchor.surface_text: Here, the accusation against the appellant was complete, and there is nothing to show that Elumalai wished to say anything more or that he had any thing more to add. In so far as the dying declaration, goes, it is a complete. Statement and makes a very clear accusation against the appellant.

issues.text: whether corroboration is necessary for a categorical and complete dying declaration

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, corroboration would not always be necessary if the dying declaration is complete in its accusation and there is nothing to show that the maker of the statement had anything further to add. That is the case here. In this case, however, there is some other evidence to incriminate the accused.

issues.text: whether the evidence warrants conviction of the appellant on a charge of murder under s.302 I.P.C.

The main argument

In that case, one Phillip Newby was shot and he made a dying declaration which was taken down but which was not complete because New by suddenly fell into a coma

arguments.claim: Accusation in dying declaration complete; no indication maker had more to say

anchor.surface_text: Here, the accusation against the appellant was complete, and there is nothing to show that Elumalai wished to say anything more or that he had any thing more to add. In so far as the dying declaration, goes, it is a complete. Statement and makes a very clear accusation

arguments.claim: No corroboration necessary for complete and categorical dying declaration per Khushal Rao v. State of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: If this dying declaration is taken into account, then it hardly needs corroboration in view of the decision of this Court in Khushal Rao v. State of Bombay. The Privy Council case, therefore, is clearly distinguishable on facts and does not apply

arguments.claim: Cyril Waugh distinguishable as incomplete lacking identity clue

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellant has relied on a case... That dying declaration, if examined clearly shows that Newby had not charged any person by name but had described his assailant as a man. In the sentence which was incomplete... a clue would have been furnished

arguments.claim: Abdul Sattar supports acting on categorical incomplete dying declaration

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council case was considered by this Court in Abdul Sattar v. Mysore State, where also the dying declaration was incomplete but was quite categoric in character and definitely indicated that it was the accused... The dying declaration was, therefore, acted upon.

arguments.claim: Other evidence sufficient/corrobates: knife recovery, sheath, blood stains, surrender, thumb injury, prior quarrel motive
Dying declaration categorical, accepts it; evidence warrants murder conviction under s.302 IPC

holdings.text: The thumb impression taken on the dying declaration after Elumalai's death must be ignored, but this was not done from any improper or dishonest motive.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt thethumbimpression of Elumalai was taken on the dying declaration after he was dead and to that extent the thumb impression must be ignored. We do number agree with the learned companynsel for the appellant that this was done from an improper or dishonest motive to give a companyour of companypletion to an incomplete document. The reason for that is number far to seek.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-Inspector noted death before taking thumb impression, testified accordingly; no evidence of motive to fabricate completion; should have left document incomplete but act not dishonest.

holdings.text: The dying declaration interrupted by sudden death is admissible in evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The fact, however, remains that the dying declaration was interrupted by death ensuing suddenly. The question is whether this dying declaration is admissible in evidence. The learned companynsel for the appellant has relied on a case of the Privy Council from Jamaica reported in Cyril Waugh v. The King 1 . In that case, one Phillip Newby was shot and he made a dying declaration which was taken down but which was number companylete because New by suddenly fell into a companya from which he never recovered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statement recorded before death; formalities post-death do not vitiate if substance complete; precedent in Cyril Waugh distinguished.

holdings.text: The dying declaration is complete as the accusation against the appellant was complete with no indication that Elumalai had more to add.

anchor.surface_text: Here, the accusation against the appellant was companylete, and there is numberhing to show that Elumalai wished to say anything more or that he had any thing more to add. In so far as the dying declaration, goes, it is a companylete. Statement and makes a very clear accusation against the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Declaration specifies date, time, place, assailant's name and weapon; speech stopped naturally after full accusation; contrasts with incomplete precedents lacking identity.

holdings.text: Corroboration is not always necessary if the dying declaration is complete in its accusation and the maker had nothing further to add.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, companyroboration would number always be necessary if the dying declaration is companylete in its accusation and there is numberhing to show that the maker of the statement had anything further to add. That is the case here. In this case, however, there is some other evidence to incriminate the accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Khushal Rao v. State of Bombay; Abdul Sattar v. Mysore State acted on similar categorical incomplete declaration; here complete accusation.

holdings.text: The evidence is sufficient to warrant the conviction of the appellant on a charge of murder under s.302 I.P.C., and the dying declaration is categorical and accepted.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Dying declaration primary; corroborated by prior oral declaration to PW1, knife recovery on accused statement, blood-stained clothes/sheath, quick surrender, thumb injury consistent with stabbing, prior quarrel motive.

holdings.text: Cyril Waugh v. The King is distinguishable and does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council case, therefore, is clearly distinguishable on facts and does number apply to the dying declaration with which we have to deal. The Privy Council case was companysidered by this Court in Abdul Sattar v. Mysore State  2 , where also the dying declaration was incomplete but was quite categoric in character and definitely indicated that it was the accused in that case who had shot the deceased.

holdings.reasoning_summary: In Cyril Waugh, declaration lacked assailant identity and incomplete sentence hinted at more (grudge clue); here full identification provided before interruption.

anchor.surface_text: Cyril Waugh v. The King 1 . In that case, one Phillip Newby was shot and he made a dying declaration which was taken down but which was number companylete because New by suddenly fell into a companya from which he never recovered. The Privy Council ruled out that dying declaration on the ground that being incomplete it companyld number be taken into account after ignoring the lost sentence

precedents.cited_proposition: incomplete dying declaration could not be taken into account after ignoring the lost sentence which was incomplete
precedents.cited_holding: ruled out that dying declaration on the ground that being incomplete it could not be taken into account

precedents.citation: Khushal Rao v. State of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Khushal Rao v. State of Bombay , . The Privy Council case, therefore, is clearly distinguishable on facts and does number apply to the dying declaration with which we have to deal. The Privy Council case was considered by this Court in Abdul Sattar v. Mysore State 2 , where also the dying declaration was incomplete but was quite categoric in character and definitely indicated that it was the accused in that case who had shot the deceased.

precedents.case_name: Khushal Rao v State of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Sattar v. Mysore State 2 , where also the dying declaration was incomplete but was quite categoric in character and definitely indicated that it was the accused in that case who had shot the deceased. The dying declaration was, therefore, acted upon. The learned counsel for the appellant attempted to distinguish Abdul Sattars case 2 on the ground that in that case there was corroboration of the dying declaration and contended that an incomplete dying declaration, if categoric in character, may be acted upon if corroborated but not if not so corroborated.

precedents.cited_proposition: incomplete dying declaration which was quite categoric in character and definitely indicated the accused was acted upon
precedents.cited_holding: dying declaration was incomplete but was quite categoric in character and definitely indicated that it was the accused in that case who had shot the deceased. The dying declaration was, therefore, acted upon

anchor.surface_text: In view of all these circumstances we are satisfied that the evidence in this case is sufficient to warrant the companyviction of the appellant on a charge of murder.

outcome.relief_summary: Evidence sufficient to warrant conviction of appellant for murder under s. 302 I.P.C.; dying declaration accepted

anchor.surface_text: No doubt thethumbimpression of Elumalai was taken on the dying declaration after he was dead and to that extent the thumb impression must be ignored. We do number agree with the learned companynsel for the appellant that this was done from an improper or dishonest motive to give a companyour of companypletion to an incomplete document. In view of all these circumstances we are satisfied that the evidence in this case is sufficient to warrant the companyviction of the appellant on a charge of murder.

anchor.surface_text: The fact, however, remains that the dying declaration was interrupted by death ensuing suddenly. The question is whether this dying declaration is admissible in evidence. The learned companynsel for the appellant has relied on a case of the Privy Council from Jamaica reported in Cyril Waugh v. The King 1 . In that case, one Phillip Newby was shot and he made a dying declaration which was taken down but which was number companylete because New by suddenly fell into a companya from which he never recovered.
In view of all these circumstances we are satisfied that the evidence in this case is sufficient to warrant the companyviction of the appellant on a charge of murder.

anchor.surface_text: Here, the accusation against the appellant was companylete, and there is numberhing to show that Elumalai wished to say anything more or that he had any thing more to add. In so far as the dying declaration, goes, it is a companylete. Statement and makes a very clear accusation against the appellant.
In view of all these circumstances we are satisfied that the evidence in this case is sufficient to warrant the companyviction of the appellant on a charge of murder.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, companyroboration would number always be necessary if the dying declaration is companylete in its accusation and there is numberhing to show that the maker of the statement had anything further to add. That is the case here. In this case, however, there is some other evidence to incriminate the accused.
In view of all these circumstances we are satisfied that the evidence in this case is sufficient to warrant the companyviction of the appellant on a charge of murder.

anchor.surface_text: In view of all these circumstances we are satisfied that the evidence in this case is sufficient to warrant the companyviction of the appellant on a charge of murder.

The Privy Council case, therefore, is clearly distinguishable on facts and does number apply to the dying declaration with which we have to deal. The Privy Council case was companysidered by this Court in Abdul Sattar v. Mysore State  2 , where also the dying declaration was incomplete but was quite categoric in character and definitely indicated that it was the accused in that case who had shot the deceased.
In view of all these circumstances we are satisfied that the evidence in this case is sufficient to warrant the companyviction of the appellant on a charge of murder.
